title: Aspiration
author: Will Blair

sections.heading: What Is Aspiration?
content: I'm Dr. John Whyte, the Chief
It's been in the news a lot
lately, and you may be wondering
are mild, but it is a highly
And if you're an older adult
With me today is Dr. Morgan
to talk about what RSV is
and how it might affect you.
Dr. Katz, thanks for joining me.

However, in the extremes of age,

Aspiration is when something you swallow "goes down the wrong way" and enters your airway (trachea or windpipe) or lungs. It can also happen when something goes back into your throat from your stomach. With aspiration, your airway isn’t completely blocked, unlike with choking.
People who have a hard time swallowing are more likely to aspirate. Up to 15 million Americans have trouble swallowing, called dysphagia. It can be temporary or part of a more serious condition.
People who might aspirate often or have problems swallowing include those who are older adults, who have had a stroke , and who have developmental disabilities.

Aspiration is when something you swallow enters your airway or lungs. It can also happen when something goes back into your throat from your stomach. People who have a hard time swallowing are more likely to aspirate. (Photo credit: Roman Samborskyi/Dreamstime)

Aspiration is when something you swallow "goes down the wrong way" and enters your airway (trachea or windpipe) or lungs. It can also happen when something goes back into your throat from your stomach. With aspiration, your airway isn’t completely blocked, unlike with choking.
People who have a hard time swallowing are more likely to aspirate. Up to 15 million Americans have trouble swallowing, called dysphagia. It can be temporary or part of a more serious condition.
People who might aspirate often or have problems swallowing include those who are older adults, who have had a stroke , and who have developmental disabilities.

Aspiration is when something you swallow enters your airway or lungs. It can also happen when something goes back into your throat from your stomach. People who have a hard time swallowing are more likely to aspirate. (Photo credit: Roman Samborskyi/Dreamstime)

sections.heading: Aspiration Symptoms
content: Sometimes, there’s no clear sign that food or liquid is going down the wrong way. Because you don't notice it, you don't cough. But in most cases, you:
bullets: Feel something stuck in your throat
Have pain when you swallow, or swallowing is hard
Cough while or after you eat or drink
Feel congested after you eat or drink
Have a gurgling or "wet-sounding" voice when you eat
Too much saliva in your mouth
Chest discomfort or heartburn
Shortness of breath or fatigue while eating
Fever within a half-hour of eating
Frequent pneumonia
Trouble chewing

content_blocks.text: Sometimes, there’s no clear sign that food or liquid is going down the wrong way. Because you don't notice it, you don't cough. But in most cases, you:
associated_bullets: Feel something stuck in your throat
Have pain when you swallow, or swallowing is hard
Cough while or after you eat or drink
Feel congested after you eat or drink
Have a gurgling or "wet-sounding" voice when you eat
Too much saliva in your mouth
Chest discomfort or heartburn
Shortness of breath or fatigue while eating
Fever within a half-hour of eating
Frequent pneumonia
Trouble chewing

sections.heading: What Causes Aspiration?
content: Your chances of aspiration go up with age, since you may have more trouble chewing and swallowing as you get older.
Other things that can cause you to aspirate are:
bullets: Seizures
Fatigue
Acid reflux
A loss of mental ability
A loss of muscle tone or coordination that interferes with how well you chew or swallow
A reaction to medication
Throat cancer
Head and neck injuries
A stroke
Nervous system disorders like amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), Parkinson's disease, and multiple sclerosis
Eating or drinking too fast
Dental problems
Mouth sores
Radiation or chemotherapy for your throat or neck
Frequent vomiting
Breathing machines or feeding tubes
Intracranial tumors
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

content_blocks.text: Your chances of aspiration go up with age, since you may have more trouble chewing and swallowing as you get older.
Other things that can cause you to aspirate are:

Dental problems

Intracranial tumors
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)

sections.heading: Silent Aspiration
content: Silent aspiration happens when you inhale a liquid, beverage, or other item into your airway without knowing. You may not have symptoms with it, and usually your body clears out the liquid or other material by coughing. If you just inhale a small amount, it's not a concern. But if you have silent aspiration regularly, you could get more serious conditions like aspiration pneumonia (a lung infection).

But if you have silent aspiration regularly, you could get more serious conditions like aspiration pneumonia (a lung infection).

sections.heading: Silent Aspiration
content: Silent aspiration happens when you inhale a liquid, beverage, or other item into your airway without knowing. You may not have symptoms with it, and usually your body clears out the liquid or other material by coughing. If you just inhale a small amount, it's not a concern. But if you have silent aspiration regularly, you could get more serious conditions like aspiration pneumonia (a lung infection).

content_blocks.text: Silent aspiration happens when you inhale a liquid, beverage, or other item into your airway without knowing. You may not have symptoms with it, and usually your body clears out the liquid or other material by coughing. If you just inhale a small amount, it's not a concern. But if you have silent aspiration regularly, you could get more serious conditions like aspiration pneumonia (a lung infection).

content: Silent aspiration differs from overt aspiration in that you can inhale things without noticing. With overt aspiration, you have abrupt and noticeable symptoms.
Signs and symptoms of silent aspiration
If you or your baby has silent aspiration, you may not have any symptoms. But some symptoms in babies can be:
Adults may have slightly different symptoms, like:
bullets: Holding their breath or breathing faster while eating
Unwilling to be fed, turning away during feedings
Having a wet-sounding cry or voice after being fed
Having repeated low-grade fevers or infections, including in the lungs
Faster breathing while eating
Congestion in the nose that goes away after eating
Wheezing or noisy breathing
Feeling that something is stuck in your throat
A buildup of mucus that affects your voice (wet sound)
Frequent infections

content_blocks.text: Silent aspiration differs from overt aspiration in that you can inhale things without noticing. With overt aspiration, you have abrupt and noticeable symptoms.
Signs and symptoms of silent aspiration
If you or your baby has silent aspiration, you may not have any symptoms. But some symptoms in babies can be:
associated_bullets: Holding their breath or breathing faster while eating
Unwilling to be fed, turning away during feedings
Having a wet-sounding cry or voice after being fed
Having repeated low-grade fevers or infections, including in the lungs

content_blocks.text: Adults may have slightly different symptoms, like:
associated_bullets: Faster breathing while eating
Congestion in the nose that goes away after eating
Wheezing or noisy breathing
Feeling that something is stuck in your throat
A buildup of mucus that affects your voice (wet sound)
Frequent infections

sections.heading: Aspiration in Children
content: Some children have trouble swallowing because of throat muscle problems caused by:
bullets: Physical conditions such as a cleft palate
Delayed growth
Brain damage
Nerve problems
Muscle diseases like spinal muscular atrophy

content_blocks.text: Some children have trouble swallowing because of throat muscle problems caused by:
associated_bullets: Physical conditions such as a cleft palate
Delayed growth
Brain damage
Nerve problems
Muscle diseases like spinal muscular atrophy

content: Common symptoms of aspiration in babies and children are similar to those of silent aspiration and can include:
bullets: Weak sucking
A red face, watery eyes, or grimacing while feeding
Breathing that speeds up or stops while feeding
A slight fever after feeding
Breathing problems like wheezing
Frequent lung or airway infections

content_blocks.text: Common symptoms of aspiration in babies and children are similar to those of silent aspiration and can include:
associated_bullets: Weak sucking
A red face, watery eyes, or grimacing while feeding
Breathing that speeds up or stops while feeding
A slight fever after feeding
Breathing problems like wheezing
Frequent lung or airway infections

sections.heading: Aspiration Diagnosis
content: Your doctor will ask about your symptoms and do a physical exam. They might look closely at your mouth and cheeks. They may also recommend that you see a specialist called a speech-language pathologist, who can check for problems with your swallowing muscles.
You might have tests such as:
bullets: X-rays. These can give your doctor an image of how much material you’ve breathed in.
Bronchoscopy. Your doctor gives you medicine to relax and puts a thin tube called a bronchoscope down your throat. It has a tiny camera to take images of the insides of your lungs.
Modified barium swallow (MBS). A technician takes X-rays of your throat and esophagus while you swallow foods and liquids that have been mixed with a chemical called barium.

Fiber-optic endoscopic evaluation of swallowing (FEES). A specialist numbs your nose. They put a thin, flexible tube called an endoscope through it and into your throat. A camera inside it takes pictures while you swallow saliva, food, and liquids.

Pharyngeal manometry. With your nose numbed, a technician puts a tube called a catheter through it and into your throat. The catheter has sensors to measure the pressure in your throat and esophagus when you swallow.

sections.heading: Aspiration Treatment
content: Treatment for aspiration begins with treating the condition that's causing it.
If you have dysphagia, treatment options vary, depending on the type:

Babies who aspirate their breast milk or formula a lot may need a change in diet that includes thickened feeds. In severe cases of aspiration, your baby may need a temporary feeding tube inserted into their nose or belly. Usually, your doctor can remove the tube when your baby is better able to swallow.
bullets: Oropharyngeal dysphagia can be treated with learning exercises and swallowing methods. These can help with proper swallowing muscle movement and nerves that control the swallowing reflex. If you have a neurological condition, swallowing techniques like proper placement of your head and body while swallowing can help.

Esophageal dysphagia treatments can include dilation, which involves placing a tube from your throat to your stomach and stretching your esophagus, medications that can reduce stomach acid (for conditions like GERD), surgery to clear the path leading to your esophagus, or a prescription for a special diet.

Severe dysphagia. If your problems are more severe, your doctor may recommend insertion of a feeding tube so that you can get nutrients without swallowing. Surgery to help with blockages or narrowing of the throat can also be treatment options. Swallowing and speech therapy may be recommended after these procedures.

content_blocks.text: Treatment for aspiration begins with treating the condition that's causing it.
If you have dysphagia, treatment options vary, depending on the type:
associated_bullets: Oropharyngeal dysphagia can be treated with learning exercises and swallowing methods. These can help with proper swallowing muscle movement and nerves that control the swallowing reflex. If you have a neurological condition, swallowing techniques like proper placement of your head and body while swallowing can help.

Esophageal dysphagia treatments can include dilation, which involves placing a tube from your throat to your stomach and stretching your esophagus, medications that can reduce stomach acid (for conditions like GERD), surgery to clear the path leading to your esophagus, or a prescription for a special diet.

Severe dysphagia. If your problems are more severe, your doctor may recommend insertion of a feeding tube so that you can get nutrients without swallowing. Surgery to help with blockages or narrowing of the throat can also be treatment options. Swallowing and speech therapy may be recommended after these procedures.

In severe cases of aspiration, your baby may need a temporary feeding tube inserted into their nose or belly. Usually, your doctor can remove the tube when your baby is better able to swallow.

sections.heading: Aspiration Pneumonia
content: Aspiration pneumonia is a lung infection caused by food, liquid, or objects being inhaled into your lungs that causes inflammation and buildup of fluid. Symptoms may come on slowly. Without treatment, they can become dangerous.
bullets: Frequent coughing with smelly mucus , blood, or pus
Wheezing or shortness of breath
Fever or chills and severe sweating
Chest pain when you cough or take a deep breath
Confusion, anxiety, and fatigue
Feeling of suffocation
Bad breath
Antibiotics. Antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia are the main form of treatment but can depend on where you got pneumonia from and any allergies to medication (like penicillin).
Oxygen therapy. Because aspiration can cause breathing trouble, extra oxygen may be needed.
Mechanical ventilation. During this treatment, a machine is breathing for you.

Wheezing or shortness of breath
Fever or chills and severe sweating
Chest pain when you cough or take a deep breath
Confusion, anxiety, and fatigue
Feeling of suffocation
Bad breath
Antibiotics. Antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia are the main form of treatment but can depend on where you got pneumonia from and any allergies to medication (like penicillin).
Oxygen therapy. Because aspiration can cause breathing trouble, extra oxygen may be needed.
Mechanical ventilation. During this treatment, a machine is breathing for you.

sections.heading: Other Complications of Aspiration
content: Aspiration can lead to more severe issues, like infection and tissue damage.
Over time, aspiration can also lead to dehydration , malnutrition, and weight loss, as well as higher chances of other illnesses.

content_blocks.text: Aspiration can lead to more severe issues, like infection and tissue damage.
Over time, aspiration can also lead to dehydration , malnutrition, and weight loss, as well as higher chances of other illnesses.

sections.heading: Aspiration Prevention
content: Try these tips to avoid aspiration when you swallow:
bullets: Eat only when you're alert and relaxed.
Cut your food into small pieces.
Eat smaller meals, and eat more often.
Add moisture, like sauce, to dry food.
Always swallow before you take another bite.
Avoid foods that stick together.
Don't talk while you eat or drink.
Don’t eat or drink while lying flat.
Use good posture while eating.
Take care of your mouth and teeth . See your dentist regularly.
Don’t smoke.
Take your time when you're eating or drinking.
Avoid heavy, fried food 3 hours before you rest (to prevent acid reflux).

Take care of your mouth and teeth . See your dentist regularly.
Don’t smoke.
Take your time when you're eating or drinking.
Avoid heavy, fried food 3 hours before you rest (to prevent acid reflux).

sections.heading: Takeaways
content: When you inhale food, a drink, or a small object and it "goes down the wrong pipe," be sure to check your symptoms. Talk to your doctor if you have a constant feeling that something is stuck in your throat. If left untreated, aspiration or silent aspiration can lead to complications like aspiration pneumonia .

content_blocks.text: When you inhale food, a drink, or a small object and it "goes down the wrong pipe," be sure to check your symptoms. Talk to your doctor if you have a constant feeling that something is stuck in your throat. If left untreated, aspiration or silent aspiration can lead to complications like aspiration pneumonia .

sections.heading: Aspiration FAQs
content: What happens when a person aspirates? When you aspirate, food, drink, or small objects you've inhaled go into the airway or lungs instead of your stomach. Usually, nerves and muscles in your throat and mouth keep food out of your lungs.

content_blocks.text: What happens when a person aspirates? When you aspirate, food, drink, or small objects you've inhaled go into the airway or lungs instead of your stomach. Usually, nerves and muscles in your throat and mouth keep food out of your lungs.

sections.heading: How do I know if I aspirated food into my lungs?
content: You will have certain symptoms if you aspirated, like pain when you swallow, coughing while or after you eat or drink, or feeling congested during these activities. If you have silent aspiration, you may not have any symptoms.

Is aspiration the same as choking? With aspiration, you inhale food, liquid, or objects into your airway or lungs . When you choke, your airway is blocked by these things. Aspiration can happen while you're choking, but it may be silent.
How long does aspiration pneumonia take to develop? Aspiration symptoms start a few hours after you inhale something and can take 1 to 2 days to develop into aspiration pneumonia.

Over time, aspiration can also lead to dehydration , malnutrition, and weight loss, as well as higher chances of other illnesses.

meta_description: Aspiration is when something enters your airway or lungs. It can also happen when something goes back into your throat from your stomach. Learn more about the symptoms, causes, risk factors, diagnosis, complications, and prevention of aspiration.
